awd_titl_txt: Laboratory Technician Support: Experimental Mineral Physics and Petrology Facilities at the University of Hawaii at Manoa
awd_abstract_narration:
Geoscientists have long recognized the importance of generating extreme conditions of pressures and temperatures to reproduce in laboratory settings the conditions present in planetary interiors. Such high-pressure experiments on the properties, transformations, and behavior of principal planetary materials provide the basis for understanding the nature and mechanisms of dynamic processes taking place within deep interiors of Earth and other planetary bodies. The many laboratories of the Mineral Physics and Experimental Petrology Laboratory (MPEPL or MPL) at the University of Hawaii at Manoa (UHM) are equipped for measurements of physical, chemical, spectroscopic, microstructural and nano-structural properties of minerals, advanced ceramics, and ceramic composites, single-crystalline and poly-crystalline minerals, silicate glasses and melts, as well as syntheses of minerals and materials under extreme conditions. This award will fund a laboratory technician in the MPL, who will play a critical role in maintaining and supporting the unique state-of-the-art experimental facilities and educational infrastructure, training students and visiting researchers, and providing technical support to the principal investigators and users of the facilities.

The lab technician will provide critical technical support for the research and educational agendas of the MPL. (1) The Multi-Anvil Press Laboratory (MAPLab) led by the lead investigator has been commissioned to become a research and teaching/training ex-situ large volume press facility for high-pressure sample syntheses and experimental petrology research. The MAPLab facilities offer a valuable platform for training junior researchers in a laboratory setting and enrich the curricula for high-pressure geosciences education. (2) The X-ray Atlas Lab led by one of the co-investigators that is engaged in cutting-edge crystallographic research focused on characterization of discontinuous structural transformations that silicates undergo as a function of depth, and has been leading the field in the development of innovative solutions in hardware, measurement methodology and data analysis software for high-pressure research. The X-ray Atlas lab provides state-of-the-art X-ray analytical capabilities for in situ and ex-situ characterization of geologic samples at both extreme and ambient conditions for broad research community on campus and off campus. The X-ray Atlas lab also features spectroscopic and laser-heating instrumentation for high-pressure and high-temperature research. (3) The Laser Spectroscopy Lab led by another co-investigator has been commissioned for measuring vibrational properties by Raman spectroscopy, Brillouin Scattering, and Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy, as well as high-temperature sample syntheses and measurements by laser heating. The lab technician will be actively involved in the research activities of all three investigators, and help to commission, maintain, and support the experimental facilities. The experimental facilities at the MPL provide opportunities for the student researchers to build their scientific resume in geoscience using the state-of-the-art multi-scale laboratories and facilities. The lab technician's active involvement in the day-to-day training of junior researchers at the UHM will have a great impact on the overall quality of graduate and undergraduate education.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF-funded project supported a laboratory technician to maintain and enhance state-of-the-art experimental and analytical facilities for mineral physics and petrology research at the University of Hawai’i at Mānoa. By enabling the seamless operation of these facilities, the project significantly advanced high-pressure mineral physics, geochemistry, and planetary science, benefiting the work of three PIs and their research groups. Research at the University of Hawai’i mineral physics laboratory focuses on understanding planetary materials under extreme pressures and temperatures found in planetary interiors. This grant ensured the optimal functioning of critical laboratories, including the Multi-Anvil Press Lab (MAPLab), X-ray Atlas Lab, and Laser Spectroscopy Lab, enabling precise and reproducible experiments on minerals and synthesized materials.


Key accomplishments included the development of advanced experimental tools and protocols. Large-volume cell assemblies for multi-anvil experiments extended the pressure range from 2 to 23 GPa, bridging the gap between piston-cylinder and higher-pressure techniques. This advancement enabled the synthesis of large samples and experimental petrology studies under extreme conditions. The Externally Heated Diamond ANvil Cell Experimentation (EH-DANCE) system was also developed as a versatile tool for high-pressure and high-temperature research. With precise pressure and temperature control and a water-cooled, vacuum-compatible enclosure, EH-DANCE system facilitated studies up to 1400 K, supporting applications such as melting temperature studies, elastic property measurements, and structural analyses using X-ray diffraction, Raman spectroscopy, and Brillouin scattering.

Advancements in Raman spectroscopy hardware and software further enhanced laboratory capabilities. A confocal Raman spectroscopy system integrated with the externally heated diamond anvil cell (EHDAC) allowed in situ characterization of elastic, structural, and vibrational properties of minerals under extreme conditions up to 1400 K. Additionally, the development of open-source software, Raman Match, streamlined Raman spectral analysis, enabling efficient mineral identification and improved data interpretation.

The X-ray Atlas Lab contributed significantly to studies of pressure-induced structural changes and crystallographic analyses of minerals. Utilizing advanced diffraction systems, such as the Bruker D8 Venture single-crystal diffractometer, the technical support has enhanced sample preparation, X-ray microanalysis, and material synthesis protocols. These capabilities supported high-impact studies on phase transformations and processes occurring in Earth’s deep interior.


Infrastructure improvements further expanded experimental capabilities. The addition of a custom UV laser drilling system for fabricating metals and ceramics has strengthened the laboratory’s research potential. Custom-machined components, such as gasketed octahedra for multi-anvil experiments and resistive heaters for externally heated diamond anvil cell experiments, were shared with the broader research community to enhance reproducibility and accessibility.


The project supported collaborative efforts with national and international institutions, advancing knowledge in planetary science, materials physics, and Earth processes. Results were widely disseminated through conferences, publications, and outreach activities, including demonstrations at major meetings such as AGU and COMPRES. Through technical innovations, collaborative research, and educational contributions, the project significantly improved high-pressure research capabilities at the University of Hawai’i at Mānoa. These advancements furthered understanding of material behavior under extreme conditions, with important implications for planetary science, geophysics, and materials engineering. The project leaves a lasting legacy of enhanced research infrastructure, advanced experimental techniques, and a skilled research community ready to address future challenges in high-pressure science.
